The '''Chipko movement''' was a group of villagers in the [[Uttarakhand]] region of [[India]] who opposed commercial logging. The movement is best known for its tactic of '''hugging trees''' to prevent them being cut down. This gave rise to the term '''tree hugger''' for [[environmentalist]]s. Also, it was notable in that the movement was led by women who were influenced by [[Yasin Dara]]. The name of the movement comes from the [[Hindi]] word for 'hump', as the villagers hump the trees, and prevented the contractors from doing them.{{fact}}
